headline: Visionless and short-sighted leadership from a bygone era.

headline: Not recommended if you're not a FA w/a book of business

cons:
Leadership is lacking from the top down, there is no company culture
The executive leaders do not reach out to the mid-level managers who do not reach out to the lower level managers
They do not believe in the client experience, or that the employee experience drives the client experience
The technology is old and no money is invested in updating
There is no workflow database programs in existence. They just fax and email paperwork to each other.
More importantly, there are no P&P publishings anywhere. They believe that individuals holding on to information increases that person's equity in the firm, so they won't codify any knowledge or proliferate because of fear of making themselves less useful. 
Takes 6 years for 401k match to become fully vested. Pay is low. Healthcare is horrible. No additional benefits (tuition, parking, etc.)

headline: Senior Financial Associate
pros:
People in the office are friendly, a lot of people have been there for DECADES in the same role so they know (sometimes) what to do / who to ask. The location is great, exposure to all resources. If you just want to be a paper pusher you can, but if you want to be more involved and work for a good financial advisor you have to take control and do it. If you work with a great/flexible advisor your life is good. If you do not then you’re SOL—management doesn’t really support associates just the producers. 

Compliance and operation managers are friendly and approachable. 

If you’re looking for just a job you go to from 8-4:30 and push papers around for mediocre pay this is the role for you.
cons:
The technology and the office are embarrassingly outdated. 

You cannot work from home (unless your advisor pays for your remote access) or from satellite branches. 

There is NO training. Processes (and being a finance firm there at A LOT of processes) are passed down from associate to associate. 

So much time is wasted trying to find the person who knows the right answer. And then another person has another opinion. It is messy. 

No room for growth. 

Your raise/bonus comes from your financial advisor (good if you work for a fair/generous human, and sad if you do not). No firm raises and your bonus is based on how many years you’ve been there (if there is a bonus) There is no annual review you get an email that is a grid “less than one year employment you get 400” “1-2 years $450” — not exact numbers but VERY close to the past year. Management is just there to sign off on paperwork. 

Benefits are expensive and mediocre. 

10 vacation days, 2 personal days, 5 sick days. 

No tuition reimbursement for MBA, CFA, CFP.

Carter Worth constantly on CNBC.
Massive product offering.
A limited few fun/entertaining coworkers.
Very helpful and friendly sales assistants and operations folks.
Positive name recognition.
Very quiet office enviroment at times... can hear a pin drop... cant be good for business, but can be relaxing at times.
cons:
If you are part time, do NOT ask to become a full time intern!
You will take a pay cut from $13 or so to minimum wage!

To broker trainees: your overall responsibility is to be a cold calling machine. You are supposed to sit down, strap in, and have the phone to your ear all day and get as many qualified leads as possible... which is not necessarily a bad thing.
You are supposed to gain training and sales experience along the way... which does not happen. Whatever you learn, you will pick up on your own along the way.
You then supply the leads to the FA you work under. If he does not call your leads and thus create new business (because hes older, wealthy, set in his ways, and lazy), you are screwed, and you're working for nothing. Demotivation and depression will soon set in, because all of your efforts are for nothing, and management will do nothing to better your situation, and youll soon face the prospect of resigning (which is my personal experience).

Your fate is in the hands of the brokers u work for.

TERRIBLE PAY.

Dead end posotion for recent college grads.

Impossible hurdles. 

Over worked, underpaid and stressed support staff.

Stressful and volatile environment when the market is down, if none of the FAs are doing any business.

Abusive and harrassing office management.  Office administrators should watch themselves or they'll get slapped with a harassment law suit soon.
